sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The familyRickettsiaceae comprises two genera of small, obligately intracellular bacteria that reside free within the host cell’s cytosol, namely, Rickettsia and Orientia. Although the number and diversity of pathogenic strains in each genus are similar, the practices of species designation differ remarkably. The second edition of Bergey’s Manual of Systematic Bacteriology lists 20 validated names of Rickettsia species, and others have been proposed (1). Strains of Orientia tsutsugamushi have 0.8% divergence of the 16S rRNA gene. Similarly, other obligately intracellular bacteria have 0.5% 16S rRNA gene divergence within a species (e.g., Ehrlichia chaffeensis, Coxiella burnetii, and Chlamydia trachomatis). The genus Rickettsia has a disproportionate number of designated species (especially within the spotted fever group) relative to the genetic divergence of the bacteria (2, 3). The criteria for the basis for these numerous species do little to aid clinical reasoning or understanding the diseases.

The genusRickettsia is divided by phylogenetic clustering into the typhus group (TG) and spotted fever group (SFG), defined originally by their distinctive lipopolysaccharide antigens, and the transitional and other ancestral groups that are widely distributed in arthropods (4). The TG consists of only two members, Rickettsia prowazekii and R. typhi, whereas the SFG contains several bacteria that are generally recognized as human pathogens (R. rickettsii, R. conorii, R. africae, R. sibirica, R. japonica, R. honei, R. parkeri, R. massiliae, R. monacensis, R. slovaca, R. aeschlimannii, R. raoultii, and R. helvetica), as well as others that have been identified only in arthropods (1, 4, 5). The transitional group, a clade between the TG and SFG, contains the pathogens R. akari, R. australis, and R. felis (6). Most Rickettsia spp. of undetermined pathogenicity, including R. amblyommatis, R. montanensis, R. bellii, R. peacockii, and R. rhipicephali, are more prevalent in U.S. ticks than is pathogenic R. rickettsii. SFG isolates originally identified in Israel and the Astrakhan region of Russia, which have wider geographic distributions, are genetic variants of R. conorii.

O. tsutsugamushi, which was once considered to be a single-species genus, diverges from Rickettsia by approximately 10% in the 16S rRNA gene and differs in its cell wall structure, containing completely unrelated proteins and lacking lipopolysaccharide (Table 1). Phylogeny based upon groEL, a member of the molecular chaperone family, reveals genetic diversity for the genus Orientia similar to that for SFG Rickettsia spp. (Fig. 1) (7, 8). O. tsutsugamushi, originally classified serologically, has subsequently been analyzed genetically. In individual geographic areas, there are several genetic variants. Phylogeny reveals nine clusters that are not identical with serotypes. The genotypes do not have strong evidence of geographic differentiation (9). Genetic variants of O. tsutsugamushi appear to correspond to particular arthropod hosts in which divergence most likely occurred. There have been changes in the genus Orientia with the addition of new candidate species. Orientia chuto sp. nov. was isolated from a patient infected in Dubai (10). This isolate has 98.5% homology to the 16S rRNA gene of O. tsutsugamushi strains Ikeda, Kato, and Karp and only 84.1 to 84.6% identity to the 47-kDa-protein gene (htrA) (10, 11). There is also genetic evidence of another member of the genus in Chile, “Candidatus Orientia chiloensis.” Analysis of material from 18 patients demonstrated ≥99.7% homology for 16S rRNA gene and htrA among patient specimens. The agent responsible for scrub typhus in Chile is likely a separate Orientia species (12). Molecular methods have detected Orientia-like DNA (94.4 to 100% similarity by the 16S rRNA gene) from rodent spleens in Africa and Europe that clusters around Orientia chuto sp. nov. and a new basal group, respectively (13).

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENERA
sect2.para: Species ofRickettsia are small (0.3 to 0.5 μm by 1 to 2 μm), obligately intracellular bacteria of the Alphaproteobacteria with a Gram-negative cell wall that contains lipopolysaccharide, peptidoglycan, a major 135-kDa S-layer protein (OmpB), a 17-kDa lipoprotein, and for SFG rickettsiae, a surface-exposed protein (OmpA) containing different numbers of nearly identical tandem repeat units (14). Rickettsia organisms have small (1.1- to 1.5-Mb), AT-rich genomes resulting from reductive evolution, with a high proportion (19 to 24%) of noncoding sequence. Among SFG and TG rickettsiae, the genomes have remarkable synteny (15). The lack of genes for enzymes for sugar metabolism, lipid biosynthesis, nucleotide synthesis, and amino acid synthesis and the presence of genes encoding enzymes for the complete tricarboxylic acid cycle and several copies of ATP/ADP translocase suggest both independent synthesis of ATP and acquisition of host ATP with rickettsial utilization of host sources for nutrition and building blocks. Rickettsiae adhere to the host cell receptor Ku70 by OmpB; by OmpA to an α2β1 integrin receptor for SFG rickettsiae; by the β-peptide of OmpA to fibroblast growth factor receptor (16); and by Sca1 and Sca2 by unknown receptors. Attachment triggers host cell signaling pathways, leading to recruitment and activation of induced phagocytosis. Rickettsiae escape from the phagosome by membranolytic activities of rickettsial phospholipase D and TlyC (17–19). O. tsutsugamushi (0.3 to 0.5 μm by 0.8 to 1.5 μm) has a 2.1-Mb genome with high proportions of genes encoding mobile genetic elements, identical repeats, and fragmented genes and a low coding capacity (20). The organisms have a major surface protein of 54 to 58 kDa as well as 110-, 80-, 47-, 42-, 35-, 28-, and 25-kDa surface proteins and an atypical peptidoglycan, but lack lipopolysaccharide. Compared with Rickettsia spp., Orientia has a more plastic Gram-negative cell wall with a thicker outer leaflet and thinner inner leaflet of the outer envelope.

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: PathogenicRickettsia spp. reside in an arthropod host (tick, mite, louse, flea, or other insect) for at least a part of their life cycle, during which they are maintained by transovarian transmission and/or cycles involving horizontal transmission to vertebrate hosts (21–24) (Table 2). Orientia spp. are maintained in nature by transovarian transmission in trombiculid mites, which transmit infection to humans during larval stage feeding (Table 2).

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: In addition to Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), rickettsialpox, murine typhus, flying squirrel-associatedR. prowazekii infection, R. parkeri infection, and Pacific coast tick fever, which are indigenous to the United States, there is significant potential for travel-related cases of African tick bite fever, boutonneuse fever, murine typhus, and scrub typhus (Table 2) (25–31). Other rickettsioses, either because of their geographic distribution and the infrequency of travelers’ exposure to them or because of their incidence, are unlikely to be travel related. RMSF, louse-borne typhus, and scrub typhus are life-threatening illnesses even for young, previously healthy persons. Murine typhus and boutonneuse fever can have a fatal outcome in patients who are elderly or have underlying diseases or other risk factors. A study of 140 patients infected with R. conorii that were admitted to Portuguese hospitals indicated that alcoholism and infection with the Israeli strain are risk factors for a fatal outcome. Fatal cases more frequently have acute renal failure, hyperbilirubinemia, obtundation, tachypnea, petechial rash, gastrointestinal symptoms, and coagulopathy (32).

An average of 7 days after tick bite inoculation of rickettsiae, patients with RMSF develop fever, severe headache, malaise, and myalgia, frequently accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain and sometimes cough (27). A rash typically appears only after 3 to 5 days of illness. Rickettsiae infect endothelial cells, frequently leading to increased vascular permeability and focal hemorrhages. In severe cases, noncardiogenic pulmonary edema may occur (33); development of encephalitis, coma, and seizures are grave conditions that cause long-term neurologic sequelae (34) and often presage death (35).

R. parkeri causes a milder illness with tick inoculation site eschar, fever, headache, myalgia, usually a maculopapular or vesiculopapular rash, less frequently tender regional lymphadenitis, and no reported deaths (36). Rickettsialpox has been recognized mainly as a nonfatal urban disease with disseminated vesicular rash and an eschar at the location of rickettsial inoculation by the feeding mite (28). R. felis infection has been recognized as having a wide geographic distribution in accordance with the ubiquitous cat flea (37). Although some reported cases exhibit signs and symptoms similar to those of other rickettsioses (38), the significance of R. felis DNA circulating within the bloodstream of both febrile subjects and afebrile controls in sub-Saharan Africa is yet to be elucidated and has caused some to raise questions regarding the true pathogenic nature of the organism (37, 39).

Murine typhus causes a rash in approximately one-half of patients. Pulmonary manifestations (cough and chest radiographic infiltrates) and mild renal dysfunction occur in some patients. In a minority, severe illness with seizures, coma, renal failure, and respiratory failure occurs (40). Although the untreated case-fatality rate is low (0.4%) (41), illness can be protracted, and severe manifestations necessitate intensive care unit admission in 10% of hospitalized cases (26).

Travelers who have returned from Africa and develop fever, one or more eschars, and in some cases regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular or vesicular rash are very likely infected withR. africae (29).

Due to their small size, ability to be aerosolized, and low infectious dose,Rickettsia species pose a danger to laboratory staff and should be handled in biosafety level 3 (BSL-3) facilities. The most pathogenic rickettsiae, R. prowazekii, R. rickettsii, R. typhi, and R. conorii, are bioterrorism threats (42).

Scrub typhus caused byO. tsutsugamushi occurs in the geographic area that is bordered by Korea and Russia on the north, Australia and Indonesia on the south, Pakistan and Afghanistan on the west, and Japan, the Philippines, and Micronesia on the east. Clinical signs and symptoms of the disease include fever, headache, maculopapular rash, eschar, interstitial pneumonia, temporary deafness, lymphadenopathy, and central nervous system involvement (43). The frequency of various manifestations may be strain dependent; the observed differences between O. tsutsugamushi organisms in the Boryong and Karp phylogenetic clades include differences in those with weakness (91% versus 61%), eschars (97% versus 74%), skin rashes (94% versus 68%), and conjunctival injection (45% versus 3%), occurring with increased frequency with organisms in the Boryong genotype (44). Without treatment, mortality can reach 30% (45). The index case of O. chuto spp. nov. and cases of “Candidatus Orientia chiloensis” are characterized by fever, inoculation eschar, rash, headache, myalgia, and lymphadenopathy (10, 46).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: For the isolation of rickettsiae, blood should be collected as early as possible in the course of illness and obtained in a sterile heparin-containing vial prior to the administration of antimicrobial agents that are active against rickettsiae (27, 47). For isolation, blood may be stored temporarily at 4°C and should be processed as promptly as possible. If inoculation of cell culture or animals must be delayed for more than 24 h, plasma, buffy coat, whole blood, or biopsied tissue should be frozen rapidly and stored at −70°C or in liquid nitrogen. EDTA- or sodium citrate-anticoagulated blood collected in the acute state has been used effectively for the diagnosis of boutonneuse fever, murine typhus, epidemic typhus, Japanese spotted fever, scrub typhus, and, with lower sensitivity, RMSF and African tick bite fever, by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) (29, 47–51). NAAT provides a higher diagnostic yield when applied to biopsy specimens of rickettsia-infected lesions, particularly eschars (32, 52–54). If whole blood, plasma, buffy coat, or tissue cannot be processed for NAAT within several days, it should be stored at −20°C or lower. Serum has a lower sensitivity for NAAT but is often diagnostic in fatal cases (55, 56). The DNA yield from eschar swabs collected for the NAAT detection of rickettsiae is adequate when swabs are stored for up to 72 h at 4°C. Collection involves using a sterile saline-dipped cotton swab vigorously rotated over an unroofed eschar (57).

sect2.para: For serologic diagnosis, blood is collected as early in the course of disease as possible, a second sample is collected after 1 or 2 weeks, and if a 4-fold rise in antibodies has not occurred, a third sample is collected 3 or 4 weeks after onset. The serum may be stored for several days at 4°C but should be stored frozen at −20°C or lower for longer periods to avoid degradation of the antibodies. However, blood samples collected by fingerstick on appropriate blotting paper in remote areas and sent by ordinary mail can be used for serologic diagnosis (58, 59). Even after transport at ambient temperature, this collection method yields serologic sensitivity similar to that of testing of fresh serum for indirect immunofluorescence assay (IFA) diagnosis of scrub typhus (59).

A 3-mm-diameter punch biopsy specimen of a skin lesion, preferably a maculopapule containing a petechia or the margin of an eschar, should be collected as soon as possible (60, 61). Although treatment should not be delayed, it is best to perform the biopsy prior to the completion of 24 h of treatment with tetracycline or chloramphenicol. For immunohistological detection of rickettsiae, the specimen can be snap-frozen for frozen sectioning or fixed in formaldehyde for the preparation of paraffin-embedded sections (28, 33, 60–64). The former approach yields a result more rapidly, but freezing artifacts distort the architecture of the tissue, and fixed tissue is more convenient for shipping to a reference laboratory. Aseptically collected autopsy tissues, e.g., spleen and lung, are useful for rickettsial isolation, ideally inoculated fresh or held for 24 h at 4°C, or stored at −70°C for longer periods if the specimen must be shipped to a public health or reference laboratory. Autopsy tissues can also be examined for rickettsiae by immunohistochemistry or NAAT.

sect1.title: General Considerations
sect1.para: NAAT and immunohistochemical diagnostic testing, the most useful methods for establishing a diagnosis during the acute stage of illness when therapeutic decisions are critical, are available at this time, to the best of our knowledge, in only a few reference laboratories. sect2.title: IMMUNOLOGIC DETECTION
sect2.para: The diagnoses of RMSF,R. parkeri infection, boutonneuse fever, African tick bite fever, murine typhus, louse-borne typhus, and rickettsialpox have been established by immunohistochemical detection of rickettsiae in formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded sections of biopsy specimens of rash and eschar lesions (61–64) (Fig. 2, left). Monoclonal antibodies that are specific for lipopolysaccharides of either SFG or TG rickettsiae have been used to detect rickettsiae by immunohistochemical staining (Fig. 2, right). There is no commercially available antibody (62, 63). The sensitivity and specificity of immunohistochemical detection of R. rickettsii in cutaneous biopsy specimens are 70% and 100%, respectively (27, 61). Eschar biopsies yield sensitive specimens for the diagnosis of SFG rickettsioses that manifest such lesions and should be considered for diagnostic evaluation in patients suspected to have rickettsialpox, R. parkeri infection, boutonneuse fever, African tick bite fever, and other SFG rickettsioses. Detection of three or more rickettsiae in vascular endothelium in biopsy specimens is diagnostic of rickettsial infection. Because histologic processing results in heat denaturation of species-specific antigens, immunohistochemistry distinguishes Rickettsia only at the SFG or TG level.

sect2.para: O. tsutsugamushi has been identified using immunohistochemistry in human endothelial cells, dendritic cells, macrophages, and cardiac myocytes (65). Skin biopsy specimens can also be utilized for the diagnosis of scrub typhus (66). Immunohistochemical staining of maculopapular skin rash samples using a mouse polyclonal antibody against O. tsutsugamushi Boryong strain had a sensitivity of 65% with a specificity of 100%. Staining of eschar lesions with the same antibody resulted in a specificity of 100% and sensitivity of 100%. No significant loss of diagnostic effectiveness was noted in patients that had eschar biopsies tested after 3 to 4 days of antibiotic treatment.

sect1.title: Rickettsia Species
sect1.para: NAAT has been applied to the amplification of the DNA of SFG and TG rickettsiae, usually from peripheral blood, buffy coat, or plasma and occasionally from fresh, frozen, or paraffin-embedded tissue and from swabs of the ulcerated bases of eschars (29, 48, 49). A variety of genes have been used for the amplification of rickettsial DNA. The targets for primer design have included the 16S rRNA gene, conserved housekeeping genes such as the citrate synthase gene (gltA), antigen genes such as those encoding outer membrane proteins (sca0 and sca5), and the 17-kDa-lipoprotein gene. No gene target seems more advantageous than another.

Conventional, nested, and real-time PCR techniques have all been used, and there are advantages and disadvantages of each method. Conventional and nested methods offer the ability to obtain larger amplicons if sequencing for the identification of a species-specific agent is desired. Real-time PCR allows quantification, high sample throughput, reduced potential for contamination, multiplexing with a variety of species- or group-specific probes, and greater analytic sensitivity. Indeed, real-time PCR has been reported to detect fewer than 10 copies of genomic DNA per reaction (67, 68). With the ability to amplify small quantities of DNA, NAAT techniques can potentially detect rickettsial organisms during the early or acute phase of disease before the generation of diagnostic antibodies. In patients treated empirically with antibiotics before diagnosis, it is slightly more sensitive (28%) than rickettsial isolation and cultivation (19%) (69). Despite the impressive analytic sensitivity of real-time PCR, it is unclear how beneficial it is when applied to clinical specimens—the sensitivity was only marginally better than that of nested NAAT performed on banked specimens (16% versus 18%) (67). A real-time reverse transcriptase assay, designed to target both 23S rDNA and rRNA from total nucleic acid, has recently been developed. With multiple copy numbers compared to pure DNA targets, the analytic sensitivity of this test appears to be 100-fold better than that of an established DNA-based real-time PCR method (70).

The limited quantities of circulating rickettsial DNA during infection greatly hinder the clinical sensitivity of molecular detection from peripheral blood specimens. The sensitivity of genus-wide NAAT using whole-blood samples ranges from 6 to 69% in studies comparing NAAT to a serologic gold standard (71–74). A critical analysis of pooled data from this literature reports a median sensitivity of 18% (75). When rickettsial DNA is detected in blood samples, it is often in patients with severe or fatal outcomes (55, 56), and when it is detected in those with RMSF, the number of copies of rickettsial DNA is greater in those who die (76). The clinical utility of NAAT is more apparent in tissue, where the sensitivity is much greater than that from peripheral blood. NAAT applied to skin biopsy specimens, particularly of eschars prior to treatment, has a sensitivity of 48 to 92% (71, 74, 77). Swabs are an effective and noninvasive method for the collection of rickettsial DNA from eschars for NAAT (57, 78–80).

A species-specific diagnosis is usually unnecessary for clinical purposes, but when the specific etiologic agent is desired for epidemiologic purposes, it can be carried out through several means. Restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis can be carried out using NAAT products using a variety of rickettsial genes and combination of restriction enzymes (81). These methods have been largely supplanted by sequencing. Probe-based real-time PCR, often multiplexed, offers the potential to differentiate infection between rickettsial groups (typhus versus spotted fever groups) or even species identification from selected agents for which targeted primers and probes are designed (74, 82, 83). NAATs to detect an array of organisms in addition to Rickettsia species have been developed. These multiplexed real-time assays have been designed for a variety of tick-borne pathogens (84), rickettsiae and leptospira (85), and both vasculotropic and leukocytic rickettsiae (86). Although some publications fail to differentiate between analytical versus clinical sensitivity and specificity, the latter assay was tested using human samples well characterized by rigorous diagnostic testing. The clinical sensitivities for detecting SFG and TG rickettsiae from blood were 25% and 20%, respectively. Specificity was 98% and 99% for SFG and TG rickettsiae, respectively (86).

Loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) assays are practical and inexpensive and have been studied for the detection of rickettsial DNA. They have good analytical sensitivity, with lower limits of detection of 5 to 100 copies of DNA per reaction (87–89). The development of a multiplexed LAMP technique with a lateral flow dipstick-based method to detect DNA by using DNA-DNA hybridization of amplicons to complementary probes has been developed (90). This technology is intriguing for implementing field-based diagnostics where various vector-borne diseases are endemic. Recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA) assays are also attractive for development to deploy in resource-limited settings. The process takes 20 minutes, it is carried out at constant temperature (37°C), results can be visualized using a lateral-flow strip, and it has a limit of detection of 10 to 50 copies of DNA per reaction (91, 92). As in the case of the aforementioned molecular methods, the paucity of circulating rickettsial organisms will likely limit the usefulness of LAMP and RPA for detection of rickettsiae from peripheral blood samples.

sect1.title: Orientia tsutsugamushi
sect1.para: NAAT forO. tsutsugamushi is typically performed on peripheral blood, buffy coat, overlying eschar crust, or tissue biopsy from an eschar. Genes often amplified include htrA, 56-kDa-protein, groEL, and the 16S rRNA gene (75). Conventional, nested, and real-time PCR have all been employed for the diagnosis of scrub typhus. The 56-kDa-protein gene is a useful target of diagnostic NAAT. A nested assay, used to amplify a 1,003-bp product followed by a 484-bp product of this O. tsutsugamushi gene, has been used with blood samples and detects 10 prototype strains (48). It is particularly useful on eschar crust, where it had an 86% sensitivity and 100% specificity in serologically confirmed cases and has good performance despite the prior use of effective antibiotics (53). Sensitivity is less when used on blood samples (81%) and diminishes after initiation of treatment (67%) (93). Considering its excellent analytical sensitivity, real-time PCR is the preferred NAAT when the equipment and technical expertise are available (75). The htrA gene is a frequently used target for real-time PCR (94) and has been applied to clinical samples (93, 95), with a sensitivity of 83% when applied to buffy coat specimens of those with serologically confirmed scrub typhus (95). Amplification of a multicopy gene, traD, may improve the ability of real-time PCR to amplify smaller quantities of DNA (96). A multiplexed real-time PCR assay for the detection of numerous rickettsia-like organisms (Rickettsia spp., O. tsutsugamushi, E. chaffeensis, and A. phagocytophilum) has a sensitivity and specificity of 27% and 100%, respectively, for identifying O. tsutsugamushi (86). It should be noted that the criteria for confirmed scrub typhus were more stringent than NAAT studies comparing results with samples already known to contain detectable O. tsutsugamushi DNA. The sensitivity of this multiplex real-time PCR is comparable to singleplex real-time PCR used in some clinical settings, as documented in a study performed on the Thailand-Myanmar border, where the sensitivity of htrA real-time PCR was 29% (73). NAAT using primers designed to amplify the 56-kDa-protein gene of O. tsutsugamushi have failed to amplify “Candidatus Orientia chiloensis,” but use of primers to amplify htrA, which is more conserved, has led to successful amplification in human cases (12). Probe-based real-time PCR is also able to amplify and distinguish “Candidatus Orientia chiloensis” from O. tsutsugamushi (97).

Similar to what has been developed for detection ofRickettsia species, LAMP and RPAs have been developed for the detection of O. tsutsugamushi and offer a simple method that can be used in locations lacking costly infrastructure. On clinical specimens, LAMP can detect 95% and 92% of those amplified by conventional and real-time PCR, respectively (98, 99). Although of potential usefulness, when compared to more stringent diagnostic criteria (established retrospectively through a combination of molecular and serologic means), LAMP for the detection of O. tsutsugamushi has a sensitivity of up to only 56% (100). LAMP using bio-optical sensor detection (iNAD) may have improved performance; it was found that iNAD had a sensitivity and specificity of 100% and 90%, respectively, in a small cohort with scrub typhus (21 cases) (101). RPA assays for the detection of the htrA gene have been developed. Testing of samples from a limited number of scrub typhus patients by RPA demonstrated positive results in 80 to 88% of samples positive by PCR (91, 102).

sect1.title: Next-Generation Sequencing
sect1.para: With the difficulty in detecting fastidious, deep-seated, or uncommon infecting pathogens, attention has been turned to the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS), where sequencing of cell-free DNA is performed to detect fragments of genomic DNA from pathogens in patient sera. These methods are intended to aid in the diagnostic approach during difficult scenarios, when routine clinical and laboratory data are unrevealing for an etiology (103). In an urban area endemic for murine typhus, mNGS using the Karius test (Karius Inc., Redwood City, CA) has helped identify R. typhi as the agent implicated in fever in 12 patients (104, 105). DNA of O. tsutsugamushi has been detected in patient specimens by mNGS. In a cohort of 10 patients, mNGS enabled confirmation of a scrub typhus diagnosis in 9 cases (106), but those tested were already clinically suspected of having scrub typhus. Thus, it is unclear if mNGS would have had an impact on patient management. In Northern Thailand, O. tsutsugamushi was detected in 11 of 200 patients with undifferentiated febrile illness (107).

The role of mNGS for routine pathogen detection—as well as detection of rickettsiae andO. tsutsugamushi—for clinical testing is currently undefined. Although it may be a helpful diagnostic modality in select situations, a multicenter study examining the clinical impact of mNGS for infectious diseases led to a positive clinical impact in only 7% and no impact in 87% of cases in which this technology was used (108). Cost, need for adequate controls, and need for adequate validation are issues that must be overcome for the effective use of mNGS (103).

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Due to their high infectivity at a low dose, isolation of rickettsiae andO. tsutsugamushi is performed in BSL-3 laboratories. Cumbersome historic methods, such as inoculation of guinea pigs, mice, or the yolk sacs of embryonated chicken eggs, have been supplanted by cell culture methods, except for isolation of O. tsutsugamushi, which is still sometimes achieved by intraperitoneal inoculation of mice (27, 47, 109). Vero, L-929, HEL, and MRC5 cells have been used in antibiotic-free media to isolate rickettsiae. The best results reported are achieved with heparin-anticoagulated plasma, buffy coat, or carefully surface-prepped, sterilely collected skin lesion biopsy specimens obtained prior to administration of antirickettsial therapy.

The shell vial technique uses samples containing 0.5 ml of triturated clinical material mixed with 0.5 ml of tissue culture medium, which is inoculated as promptly as possible onto 3.7-ml shell vials with 12-mm-diameter round coverslips having a confluent layer of cells, then centrifuged at 700 ×g for 1 h at room temperature to enhance attachment and entry of rickettsiae into host cells (47). After removal of the inoculum, the shell vials are washed with phosphate-buffered saline and incubated with minimal essential medium containing 10% fetal calf serum in an atmosphere containing 5% CO2 at 34°C. At 48 and 72 h, a coverslip is examined by Giemsa or Gimenez stain or by immunofluorescence with antibodies against SFG and TG rickettsiae. Detection of four or more organisms is interpreted as a positive result. This method has yielded a diagnosis in 59% of samples from patients with boutonneuse fever who had neither been treated nor developed antibodies to R. conorii prior to collection of the sample (47). Rickettsiae were detected at 48 h of growth in 82% of the positive samples. Incubating at lower temperatures (28°C or 32°C) may be beneficial for some suspected pathogens, specifically R. felis and R. massiliae (110, 111). Earlier detection of rickettsiae is possible when the shell vial medium is tested by real-time PCR (109). Similar techniques have been applied to 24-well plates (112) or to small cell culture flasks (109). Small cell culture flasks have been used in Laos, where isolates are obtained in 26% of those with scrub typhus and 4% of those with murine typhus (confirmed by serology or NAAT). Universal precautions should be exercised, and work should be performed within a biosafety cabinet located in a BSL-3 laboratory with proper personal protective equipment. Although the quantity of rickettsiae in the cell culture is relatively low, aerosol or contact exposure should be avoided as for mycobacteria, fungi, and viruses.

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION OF RICKETTSIA AND ORIENTIA ISOLATES
sect2.para: Rickettsiae isolated in cell culture can be identified by indirect immunofluorescence with group-, species-, and strain-specific monoclonal antibodies. Rickettsial isolates are frequently identified by molecular methods such as NAAT of genes that are genus specific (17-kDa-protein gene, citrate synthase gene, orsca5) or SFG specific (sca0) (77). Alternatively, species-specific probes can be coupled with real-time PCR (83). NGS has been used to help determine the specific agent implicated in clinically suspected SFG rickettsioses in China (113, 114). Determination of DNA sequences identifies unique isolates. O. tsutsugamushi, being more distantly related to Rickettsia spp., lacks the above-mentioned cell surface protein genes but can be identified by NAAT of the gene encoding the major immunodominant 56-kDa surface protein, the 47-kDa-protein gene, groEL, or the 16S rRNA gene (53, 75).

Historically, species identification of rickettsial isolates was performed by microimmunofluorescence serotyping. This rather cumbersome and expensive method required propagation of large quantities of the isolate and prototype strains for immunofluorescence titration and the development of typing sera by the intravenous inoculation of mice. Genetic analysis is currently favored for identification of isolates. An isolate that is known to be aRickettsia spp. should be identified in a BSL-3 laboratory, and isolates of R. prowazekii must be handled as required by U.S. federal regulations for select agents.

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: For most clinical microbiology laboratories, assays for antibodies to rickettsiae are the only tests, if any, performed. This situation is unfortunate for the patient with a life-threatening, acutely incapacitating rickettsial disease, because these assays are useful principally for serologic confirmation of the diagnosis in convalescence and usually do not provide information that is helpful in making critical therapeutic decisions during the acute stage of illness. Patients who die of rickettsioses usually have received many antibiotics, none of which has antirickettsial activity, owing in part to the lack of specific laboratory data providing clinical guidance for a rickettsial disease diagnosis. The earlier a diagnosis is established, the shorter the course and severity of rickettsial illness will be after an appropriate antirickettsial antibiotic is administered.

The assays that were historically most widely used for the diagnosis of rickettsial diseases are agglutination of the OX-19 and OX-2 strains ofProteus vulgaris for TG and SFG rickettsioses and the OX-K strain of Proteus mirabilis for O. tsutsugamushi infections. These assays have poor sensitivity and specificity (61). They should be replaced by more accurate serologic methods, such as IFA or EIA. However, there are situations in developing countries where the choice is between the Proteus agglutination tests and none at all for the detection of important public health problems, such as outbreaks of louse-borne typhus (115). In fact, the evidence leading to the discoveries of Japanese spotted fever and Flinders Island spotted fever included Proteus-agglutinating antibodies.

Serologic assays for the diagnosis of rickettsial infections focus on the “gold standard,” the IFA. Other approaches include indirect immunoperoxidase assay (IPA), latex agglutination, enzyme immunoassay (EIA), line blotting, Western blotting, and rapid lateral-flow assays (61, 116–122). Only some of these assays are available as commercial kits or in reference laboratories, and they are not available for all rickettsial diseases. Other serologic tests, such as indirect hemagglutination, microagglutination, and complement fixation, are no longer in general use.

sect1.title: Rickettsia Species
sect1.para: The IFA contains all the rickettsial heat-labile protein antigens and group-shared lipopolysaccharide antigen and, thus, provides group-reactive serology. IFA reagents are available commercially for SFG and TG rickettsiae from BIOCELL Diagnostics (Baltimore, MD), Scimedx Corp. (Dover, NJ), Focus Diagnostics (Cypress, CA), and Fuller Laboratories (Fullerton, CA). In cases of RMSF, IFA detects antibodies at a titer of ≥64, usually in the second week of illness. Effective antirickettsial treatment of RMSF must be initiated by day 5 of illness to avoid a potentially fatal outcome. For boutonneuse fever, an IFA titer of ≥40 occurs in 46% of patients between days 5 and 9 of illness, in 90% of patients between days 20 and 29, and in 100% of patients thereafter. In murine typhus, diagnostic IFA titers are present in 50% of cases by the end of the first week of illness and in nearly all cases by 15 days after onset (26). In areas where particular rickettsial diseases are endemic, a higher diagnostic cutoff titer is required, but there is no consensus on how cutoffs are chosen (123). Each laboratory performing the test should establish its own cutoff titers for the patient population, the microscope and reagents used, and the laboratorian’s judgment of the minimal positive signal.

IPA for murine typhus, boutonneuse fever, and presumably other rickettsioses yields results similar to those of IFA when the IgG diagnostic titer is set at 128 and that of IgM is set at 32 (124). Advantages include the use of a light microscope rather than a fluorescence microscope and the production of a permanent slide result. Latex agglutination test reagents are available commercially from Scimedx Corp., only for R. rickettsii in the United States. Latex beads coated with an extracted rickettsial protein-carbohydrate complex containing rickettsial lipopolysaccharide are agglutinated mainly by IgM antibodies, with reports of a sensitivity of 71 to 94% and a specificity of 96 to 99% (119). A diagnostic titer of 128 is often detected early in the second week of illness.

EIAs have been developed in various formats, including antigens coating microtiter wells or immobilized on nitrocellulose or other sheets for use in the commercial reference laboratory setting. When compared with an IFA titer of ≥64 for the diagnosis of murine typhus, the dot-EIA showed a sensitivity of 88% and specificity of 91% (125). The dot-EIA for R. conorii antigen provided early diagnostic evidence of an SFG rickettsiosis. Subsequent analysis revealed poor specificity, with a high rate of false-positive results. These assays are diagnostic tools that do not require expensive, specialized equipment, but they suffer from apparent low specificity. Standard EIAs for detecting IgG or IgM antibodies against SFG and TG rickettsiae are available from Fuller Laboratories. An examination of these for the diagnosis of murine typhus performed well in a PCR-confirmed cohort when specimens were tested in both the acute and convalescent phases (126).

Shared antigens of OmpA, OmpB, and group-specific lipopolysaccharide impede establishment of a species-specific diagnosis by serologic methods. The criterion of a 4-fold or greater difference in IFA titers between the two suspected agents distinguished infections byR. prowazekii and R. typhi in only 34% of cases and infections by R. africae from those by R. conorii in only 26% (29, 127). Western blotting detection of antibodies against OmpA or OmpB of only one Rickettsia species has also been proposed as a criterion for species-specific diagnosis. However, it was effective in distinguishing R. prowazekii and R. typhi infections or R. africae and R. conorii infections in only one-half of the cases (29, 127, 128). Cumbersome, expensive cross-absorption of sera prior to IFA or Western immunoblotting is more effective in establishing a species-specific diagnosis. However, interpretation of these results requires careful evaluation of the performance of valid controls, the quality and quantity of each antigen preparation, and the potential for the occurrence of infection by an untested, even as-yet-undiscovered, agent. In the past, knowledge of the geographic origin of the case sufficed to designate the specific diagnosis. However, the increasing number and geographic overlap of rickettsioses challenge the old assumptions.

sect1.title: Orientia tsutsugamushi
sect1.para: When coupled with acute- and convalescent-phase sera, IFA continues to remain the gold standard for the diagnosis of scrub typhus (75). Reagents are available commercially from Scimedx Corp., BIOCELL Diagnostics, and Fuller Laboratories. The IFA test is not without limitations, which include cost, need for a fluorescent microscope, availability of a trained microscopist, subjectivity of interpreting endpoint titers, need for paired specimens, and consideration of cutoffs based on the regional seroprevalence. Meta-analysis of IFA serology for the diagnosis of scrub typhus led to recommendations that diagnosis be based on a 4-fold or greater rise in titer and that diagnosis not be based on a single antibody titer unless previous studies had determined the seroprevalence in the local population, justifying the cutoff titer (129). The persistence of reactive IgM for 1 year and IgG for 3 years after scrub typhus infection is problematic when single acute-phase specimens alone are considered for diagnostic purposes (130). When sera are tested only in the acute phase, the performance of IFA to reliably detect antibodies at manufacturer-suggested cutoffs is poor. An evaluation of IFA assays from various companies, using single acute-phase specimens, demonstrated the sensitivity of IgM was 56% and 64%, both with a specificity of 95%, at suggested manufacturer cutoffs of 16 and 64, respectively. The sensitivity of IgG was 42% and 67% at cutoffs of 256 and 128, respectively. Specificities of IgG at these cutoffs were 96% and 74%, respectively (131). Using the modified scrub typhus infection criteria, an admission cutoff IgM IFA titer of ≥3,200 or a >4-fold rise to ≥3,200 in titers in paired convalescent-phase samples is required (129). The sensitivity and specificity of the IgM IFA are 81.6% and 100%, using the modified scrub typhus infection criteria (132). IPA for scrub typhus is comparable to IFA (124) but, other than requiring only a light microscope, has similar limitations to IFA.

EIA has become an increasingly used method to detect antibodies reactive againstO. tsutsugamushi. Its simplicity, lack of subjectivity, and reproducibility are desired attributes (75). Both whole-cell antigen and recombinant proteins (usually to the 56-kDa protein) have been used for these assays (133, 134). Since remarkable diversity of O. tsutsugamushi strains is often present in a limited geographic distribution, antigens from several strains are used (135). A novel conserved O. tsutsugamushi 27-kDa protein found through immunoinformatic analysis may offer a simple and effective approach to assay design (136). As with IFA, validated cutoffs are still required. The use of Bayesian latent class modeling has allowed for determination of optimal cutoff values, aids in the ability to estimate accuracy of testing, and does not require comparison to a gold standard (137).

There are currently several serology-based rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) available. The use of lateral-flow immunochromatographic strips in these tests offers a rapid and easy-to-use diagnostic modality. Companies manufacturing these include InBios (Seattle, WA), Standard Diagnostics Inc. (Suwon, South Korea), and ImmuneMed (Seoul, South Korea). A meta-analysis examining data from studies using various RDTs revealed a pooled sensitivity of 66% and specificity of 92% (it should be noted that the methods for these studies were quite heterogenous, so care in interpreting the analysis should be considered) (138). The characteristics of RDTs on acute samples demonstrated sensitivities of 54%, 36%, and 73% with specificities of 100%, 100%, and 90% for IgM, IgG, and total immunoglobulin, respectively (131). Both studies emphasize the limitations of using single acute-phase specimens. Another study of three RDTs showed better sensitivity (87 to 92%) but lower specificity (86 to 92%) (99), likely reflecting variabilities in study design.

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Data supporting the use of doxycycline or another tetracycline antibiotic as the drug of choice for the treatment of infections caused byRickettsia spp. and the use of chloramphenicol as an alternative drug have been derived principally by observational data and a few prospective studies (139–143). Techniques to determine in vitro susceptibilities of these obligately intracellular bacteria are not standardized as they are for other bacteria. In addition to historic studies of the activity of antimicrobial agents against these obligately intracellular bacteria in infected animals and embryonated eggs, studies of the effects of antimicrobial agents in cell culture have supported the use of tetracyclines and chloramphenicol (144). In vitro studies have also supported the consideration of alternative drugs, such as fluoroquinolones, some macrolides (i.e., azithromycin and clarithromycin), and newer tetracycline-like antibiotics (i.e., eravacycline, omadacycline, and tigecycline) (144, 145). Indeed, ciprofloxacin, clarithromycin, and azithromycin have been used successfully for the treatment of boutonneuse fever under certain circumstances (139, 141, 143), but they cannot be recommended for the most severe rickettsioses—RMSF and louse-borne epidemic typhus. A controlled trial in patients with murine typhus demonstrated that azithromycin was inferior to doxycycline based on time to defervesce and failure rate (146). Based on the time-to-defervescence criterion used by the aforementioned trial, retrospective data suggesting that ciprofloxacin is effective for murine typhus should be interpreted with caution (mean time to defervesce on ciprofloxacin was 4.2 days) (140).

In vitro susceptibility does not always predict efficacy, as in the case of rifampin, where the MIC for various Rickettsia spp. ranges from 0.06 to 1.0 μg/ml (144), but clinical failures have occurred (147). Chloramphenicol has been used to treat RMSF during pregnancy, but it is difficult to procure in the United States and appears inferior to doxycycline (148). Since there are few data to support the idea that doxycycline causes harm in the developing fetus, as is the case with tetracycline hydrochloride, the benefits of doxycycline for RMSF far outweigh the risks (149). Azithromycin can be considered for less severe rickettsioses (e.g., boutonneuse fever) in pregnant women. There is little concern regarding rickettsial development of antimicrobial resistance, and antimicrobial susceptibility studies of rickettsiae are not routinely performed clinical laboratory tests (150).

As with the aforementioned rickettsiae, doxycycline is the historical drug of choice for infection withO. tsutsugamushi, but chloramphenicol, azithromycin, and clarithromycin appear to be similarly effective as analyzed by systematic reviews of prospective and observational studies (151, 152). Unlike the case with Rickettsia spp., rifampin is effective in those with scrub typhus (152). Azithromycin has been used successfully in cases of scrub typhus in Thailand which have not responded to doxycycline or chloramphenicol (153). The reasons for the poor performance of doxycycline in these patients are not well understood; reduced susceptibility of O. tsutsugamushi to doxycycline is controversial (154, 155). In contrast, albeit based on retrospective observation and subject to bias, delayed responses to azithromycin have been reported in South India (156). It is not known if pharmacodynamic/pharmacokinetic issues, regional strain differences in antimicrobial susceptibility, or host factors play a role. O. tsutsugamushi is intrinsically resistant to fluoroquinolones (157). Research efforts to improve and streamline antibiotic testing for O. tsutsugamushi through real-time PCR show promise, but use is still limited to BSL-3 facilities (158).

sect2.title: INTERPRETATION AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: When reporting the results of an assay for antibodies in a single serum sample, the laboratorian seldom knows the duration of illness and whether the serum sample is from the acute or the convalescent phase of the disease. For sera that are nonreactive by dot-EIA, by IFA at a dilution of 1:64, by indirect immunoperoxidase assay at a dilution of 1:128, by latex agglutination at a dilution of 1:64, or by Weil-FelixProteus agglutination at a titer of 1:160, the laboratory report should state that no antibodies were detected at the particular cutoff dilution, which may differ among some laboratories and some patient populations; that negative results are expected in the acute stage of rickettsial illness; and that a second sample should be submitted to evaluate the possibility of seroconversion if no alternative diagnosis has been established. If paired acute- and convalescent-phase sera separated by an appropriate interval are available, they should be tested simultaneously. It is wise to test for all the rickettsial and ehrlichial agents to which the patient is likely to have been exposed in the United States. SFG rickettsiae, E. chaffeensis, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, and R. typhi are the likely agents, unless travel to an area where scrub typhus or African tick bite fever is endemic has occurred. If the paired sera fail to demonstrate a 4-fold increase in titer, the report should state that the results do not support the diagnosis of rickettsial infection but that occasionally antibody synthesis is delayed, particularly in cases with early antirickettsial therapy. If a single serum sample contains an IFA antibody titer of ≥64, an IFA IgM titer of ≥32, an indirect immunoperoxidase antibody titer of ≥128, or a latex agglutination titer of ≥64, the laboratory report should state that antibodies reactive with the particular rickettsial antigen were detected at the measured titer, that the result provides supportive evidence for the diagnosis of the rickettsial disease, and that a convalescent-phase sample should be submitted to assess the possibility of a diagnostic rise in titer.

The reactive single serum sample is problematic. In a study of individuals from an area where RMSF is endemic, IgM seroreactivity toR. rickettsii was not predictive of a dynamic rise in subsequent IgM titers or IgG seroconversion (159). In an analysis of SFG rickettsioses in the United States, less than 1% of cases are confirmed through use of paired specimens, culture, IHC, or NAAT detection of rickettsial DNA. Of the 99% considered probable cases, 82% were based on a single antibody test and 72% were collected during the first week of illness (often a noncompatible illness), within the period of time before SFG antibodies are expected to be produced (160). If paired sera measured simultaneously show a 4-fold or greater rise in titer, the interpretation is that the results strongly support the rickettsial diagnosis indicated by the tested antigen. If a significant titer is detected in the acute-phase sample, but no rise or only a single doubling dilution rise was measured, it should be stated that an additional later sample should be tested to evaluate a 4-fold rise or fall in titer. The concept that recrudescent typhus could be distinguished from primary louse-borne typhus by the absence of IgM antibodies to R. prowazekii and of Proteus OX-19-agglutinating antibodies has been challenged (118). The manufacturers of the dot-EIA have recommended the interpretation that strongly reactive samples (three or four dots) may indicate the presence of a specific antibody response and that weakly reactive samples (one or two dots) are infrequent but possible in normal populations. Retesting 2 to 3 weeks later would establish the diagnosis if three or four dots develop in the convalescent-phase serology and should always be performed. It is important to understand that healthy persons can have serum antibodies reactive with SFG rickettsiae. The seroprevalence in healthy blood donors in the state of Georgia, an area of SFG rickettsiosis endemicity, is 11%, and in Oregon, an area presumed to have fewer SFG rickettsioses, the seroprevalence is 6% (161). It is also important to understand that patients with Rocky Mountain spotted fever generally do not develop antibodies to R. rickettsii during the first week of illness. Thus, antibodies detected earlier than this time likely preexist the febrile illness.

Isolation of a rickettsia from blood or tissue may be interpreted as indicating an etiologic role. The level of identification of the isolate should be stated, whether identified only as SFG or TG or to the species level.

Immunohistological diagnostic interpretation states the method, reactivity of the method (e.g., antibody reactive with SFG rickettsiae), and location of the antigen (e.g., in vascular endothelium and frequently adjacent vascular smooth muscle forR. rickettsii).

Interpretation of NAAT results should state the target gene, the organisms that would be detected, and the presence or absence of a nucleic acid product. If a specific oligonucleotide probe or DNA sequencing confirmed the specificity of the identification, this result should be stated. For negative immunohistological and NAAT results, it should always be stated that the failure to detect the agent does not exclude the diagnosis, along with data regarding the sensitivity and specificity of the assay in the particular laboratory, if known, and the effects of antirickettsial treatment on the sensitivity.

Special efforts should be made, in coordination with the CDC, to establish the diagnosis of fatal cases, which include performing rickettsial isolation, immunohistology, NAAT, and serology on samples collected at necropsy.
